subject: How to count test assertions
msgSnippet: JUnit (3.8.1) counts the number of test methods that pass/fail. With some of the test generation methods, such as JUnitDoclet, empty methods are generated (a
messageBody:
JUnit (3.8.1) counts the number of test methods that pass/fail.
With some of the test generation methods, such as JUnitDoclet, empty
methods are generated (a good thing) for each class. But when the
tests are run, the generated document shows that all these methods
pass (questionably good). This gives a false sense that the code
being tested is being tested, when it really isn't because the test
bodies are empty.

Is there a way to track the number of assertions that pass/fail
instead of the number of methods that are invoked in the test classes?
This way the numbers reported (e.g., 122 tests run) would tend to
imply better test coverage, or at least more actual tests executing,
rather than lots of empty tests running. (Yes, I know bad tests can
be written that skew the results, but we don't need to go into that
now.)
This way more the classes for which tests haven't yet been written,
but the skeleton is up and running, would show up in the report as 0
tests run, rather than whatever number of test skeletons have been
generated
and may or may not be empty.

Thanks,
Steve Kelem
